We believe that greater transparency will help lead the change towards a more sustainable future. As a step in this long-term commitment, we’re sharing how and where our products are made wherever possible.

Cotton is the fibre we use the most, but it’s a challenging material that needs a lot of water to grow. Our aim is for all our cotton to be sustainably sourced by 2020. Currently, we’re using three types of sustainably sourced cotton: organic cotton, which is grown without chemical pesticides and fertilisers, and contains no genetically modified organisms; recycled cotton, which comes from used garments and textile leftovers; and cotton sourced through the BCI (Better Cotton Initiative), which helps reduce stress on the local environment and improves the welfare of farming communities.

Conventional polyester is a commonly used artificial fibre made from fossil resources (crude oil). We are constantly striving to increase our use of recycled polyester; a more sustainable option made from waste such as plastic (PET) bottles. We are also engaging heavily in developing technologies that will enable textile-to-textile recycling, to further improve the sustainability of recycled polyester and save natural resources.

Conventional nylon/polyamide is a commonly used artificial fibre made from oil which is a fossil resource. We are constantly striving to increase our use of recycled nylon, which is made from waste such as old fishing nets, carpets, and industrial waste. We are also engaging in the development of other sustainable nylon options, such as bio-based nylon.

Lyocell is a regenerated cellulose fibre commonly made from wood, but the raw material could also consist of other cellulosic material. This renewable material comes from sources that need little or no irrigation or pesticides, making it a more sustainable option than cotton. According to Textile Exchange, H&M is one of the world’s biggest users of TENCEL™ branded lyocell fibres, which are derived from sustainable wood sources and produced in an environmentally responsible closed loop production process.

Wool is a natural fibre sourced from sheep, and is insulating, odour resistant and durable. While wool is a renewable and biodegradable material, it can be connected with risks such as animal welfare. We believe strongly in respecting animal welfare, and only work with suppliers who follow our Animal Welfare Policy. We are also constantly striving to increase our use of recycled wool, organic wool and Responsible Wool Standard (RWS) certified wool . Recycled wool comes from production cut-offs and used textile products. Using recycled wool saves natural resources and reduces waste going to landfill.

Conventional acrylic is a commonly used artificial fibre made from oil which is a fossil resource. We are engaging in research to develop sustainable alternatives to conventional acrylic or substitute it for other fibres.

Conventional elastane is a commonly used fibre which gives fabric elasticity. The fibre is made from oil which is a fossil resource. We are exploring the development of sustainable alternatives to conventional elastane, such as recycled elastane and bio-based elastane.

Leather is a durable material made from animal hides; commonly used in apparel, footwear and interior products throughout the world. At H&M, all leather and suede come from animals that have been bred for meat production, as outlined in our strict Animal Welfare Policy. We are also exploring the development of non-animal leather alternatives, such as from agricultural waste.

Leather is a durable material made from animal hides; commonly used in apparel, footwear and interior products throughout the world. At H&M, all leather and suede come from animals that have been bred for meat production, as outlined in our strict Animal Welfare Policy. We are also exploring the development of non-animal leather alternatives, such as from agricultural waste.

Leather is a durable material made from animal hides; commonly used in apparel, footwear and interior products throughout the world. At H&M, all leather and suede come from animals that have been bred for meat production, as outlined in our strict Animal Welfare Policy. We are also exploring the development of non-animal leather alternatives, such as from agricultural waste.

Suede is a durable material made from animal hides; commonly used in apparel, footwear and interior products throughout the world. At H&M, all leather and suede come from animals that have been bred for meat production, as outlined in our strict Animal Welfare Policy. We are also exploring the development of non-animal leather alternatives, such as from agricultural waste.

Suede is a durable material made from animal hides; commonly used in apparel, footwear and interior products throughout the world. At H&M, all leather and suede come from animals that have been bred for meat production, as outlined in our strict Animal Welfare Policy. We are also exploring the development of non-animal leather alternatives, such as from agricultural waste.

Suede is a durable material made from animal hides; commonly used in apparel, footwear and interior products throughout the world. At H&M, all leather and suede come from animals that have been bred for meat production, as outlined in our strict Animal Welfare Policy. We are also exploring the development of non-animal leather alternatives, such as from agricultural waste.

Conventional polyurethane (PU) coating is made from oil which is a fossil resource and is commonly used worldwide in products like rainwear and footwear. We are phasing out the common solvent DiMethylFormamide (DMF) from the PU production and are also looking into more sustainable versions, such as bio-based PU and other alternatives made from agricultural waste.

Linen is a durable material made from flax plants. Linen has a good sustainability profile but we are also striving to increase our use of organic linen, which comes from plants grown without chemical pesticides or fertilisers. This is favourable for both the health of farmers and the environment.
Cupro is a regenerated cellulose fibre made from cotton linter: a waste product from the cotton industry. For this reason, Cupro can be considered a recycled and sustainable material.

Viscose is a regenerated cellulose fibre commonly made from wood, but the raw material could also consist of other cellulosic material. We are aiming to ensure that all wood used to make cellulosic fibres comes from sustainably managed forests or plantations. We are also engaging in research and development of recycled viscose made of used cotton textiles, and are also actively working with developing more sustainable processes to create viscose like fibres.

Modal is a regenerated cellulose fibre commonly made from wood, but the raw material could also consist of other cellulosic material. We are aiming to ensure that all wood used to make cellulosic fibres comes from sustainably managed forests or plantations.

Acetate is a regenerated cellulose fibre commonly made from wood, but the raw material could also consist of other cellulosic material. We are aiming to ensure that all wood used to make cellulosic fibres comes from sustainably managed forests or plantations. We are also engaging in the development of acetate made from alternative raw materials, such as agricultural waste and used cotton textiles.

Plastics contains a variety of different materials called polymers; the specific type is chosen depending on the application. Most plastics used today are made from fossil oil. At H&M, we are striving to increase the use of recycled plastic, as well as exploring the use of bio-based plastics.
Our goal is to use 100% recycled or other sustainably sourced materials by 2030.

Down is plucked from birds to use as insulation materials in apparel, interior products etc. At H&M, all down and feather originate from birds bred for food production, and we never accept materials from live plucked birds. We also require certification according to the Responsible Down Standard (RDS). We have also started to use recycled down from used blankets, pillows and cushions.

Down is plucked from birds to use as insulation materials in apparel, interior products etc. At H&M, all down and feather originate from birds bred for food production, and we never accept materials from live plucked birds. We also require certification according to the Responsible Down Standard (RDS). We have also started to use recycled down from used blankets, pillows and cushions.

Feather is plucked from birds to use as insulation materials in apparel, interior products etc. At H&M, all down and feather originate from birds bred for food production, and we never accept materials from live plucked birds. We also require certification according to the Responsible Down Standard (RDS).

Metals have a variety of useful properties and are usually extremely durable. Mining and extraction of ore can be challenging for the environment. We are exploring ways to use more sustainable versions of metals, such as recycled metals.

Wood comes from trees originating from natural forests or plantations. While wood is a renewable and biodegradable material, it can be connected with risks such as deforestation. At H&M, we use FSC certification to guarantee sustainable forest management for wood originating from countries with tropical rainforest or ancient and/or endangered forests, as outlined in our Material Ethics Policy.

Ceramics contain a variety of different materials, commonly referred to as stoneware, earthenware and porcelain. Ceramic materials are traditionally made from clay and can be treated in different ways to achieve different properties and looks.

Ceramics contain a variety of different materials, commonly referred to as stoneware, earthenware and porcelain. Ceramic materials are traditionally made from clay and can be treated in different ways to achieve different properties and looks.

Ceramics contain a variety of different materials, commonly referred to as stoneware, earthenware and porcelain. Ceramic materials are traditionally made from clay and can be treated in different ways to achieve different properties and looks.
Paraffin is a white, odourless and colourless material made from oil which is a fossil resource. It is commonly used to make candles and burns reliably.

Wax is a diverse class of material that can come from natural sources, such as animals and plants, or be petroleum-based. At H&M we are using different varieties, but we strive to increase the use of plant wax. We’re committed to ensuring that the natural raw materials used in our products are produced in a responsible way, as outlined in our Material Ethics Policy.

Glass is made out of sand that has been treated at very high temperatures and turned into a liquid. The molten glass can then be made into various shapes and given different properties like transparency, strength and temperature resistance. Glass is a fully recyclable material and at H&M we strive to increase our use of more sustainable recycled glass.

Cashmere is a luxurious natural fibre derived from goats, which is insulating, soft and strong. We believe strongly in respecting animal welfare, and only work with suppliers who follow our strict Animal Welfare Policy. We’re constantly striving to increase our use of recycled cashmere, which comes from cut-offs created during production and used textile products. Using recycled cashmere saves natural resources and reduces landfill waste.

Alpaca is a luxurious natural fibre that comes from the animals’ hair, and is insulating, hypoallergenic and soft. At H&M we strongly care about animal welfare, and only work with suppliers who follow our strict Animal Welfare Policy.

Silk is a luxurious and highly absorbent fibre. Most silk used for textiles come from the mulberry silkworm and is obtained from the cocoon of the larvae. When suppliers source silk for H&M products, they must follow our strict Material Ethics Policy.At H&M, we also use organic silk, which guarantees that the mulberry trees the silk worms have been living in are grown in an environmentally friendly way. We don’t allow silk originating from India due to poor working conditions in the Indian silk industry.

Jute is a fibre extracted from the bark of the white jute plant and used for making baskets, rugs, footwear etc. Jute requires only low amounts of water and chemicals to be grown and is hence a good sustainable option.
This product has been produced in one of the following countries:
Suppliers and factories for this product.

All our products are made by independent suppliers, often in developing countries where our presence can make a real difference. Our business helps to create jobs and independence, particularly for women — consequently lifting people out of poverty and contributing to economic growth.
We only work with partners who share our respect for people and the environment, and who are willing to work with us to improve their practices. All suppliers and factories must sign our strict Sustainability Commitment, which includes requirements for fair wages and good working conditions for all. We employ dedicated sustainability staff in our worldwide production offices to make sure the commitment is followed.
You too can help the environment and make fashion more sustainable. Bring unwanted clothes or home textiles to any H&M store and they will be reworn, reused or recycled.

We believe that greater transparency will help lead the change towards a more sustainable fashion future. As a first step in this long-term commitment, we’re sharing how our products are made wherever possible.
Unfortunately, supplier and factory information isn’t currently available for this product. Thank you for being patient while we work towards displaying these details for all H&M items possible.
These suppliers and factories made this product for H&M globally, which means that the item you will receive is produced by one of these suppliers and one of their factories.
We want to be completely transparent with you about how and where our products are made, and we have a new system for this.

However, if an item was produced before we started using our new system, all the supplier information may not be available. We’re focusing our efforts on making sure all items going forwards display all supplier details.
If we stop working with a supplier or factory, we’ll only display the last information that we had at the point of collaboration.
Thank you for bearing with us while we work towards greater transparency.

Your privacy is important to us which is why we want to inform you on our updated Privacy Notice. To give you a more transparent and clear information on how we process your personal data, we have divided the Privacy Notice into different chapters. Depending on if you are a subscriber, member or if you have an H&M Account, different parts of the notice will apply to you. In each chapter, we describe in more detail what personal data we have about you and how we use it. We have also increased the information on your rights, for example how to get access to your data and how you can request to terminate the usage of your data.

Here’s a selection of items that we think will suit you based on your quiz answers. We hope you like it!
Smart everyday wear for the modern man.

Smart everyday wear for the modern man. This style is always current, masculine and urban — from work to leisure, from day to night. This selection ranges from smart essentials to seasonal key products, relevant for all occasions. Inspiration is taken from leading designers and high end brands that influence commercial fashion.
The latest trends in streetwear fashion.

The latest trends in street-wear fashion. The foundation of this style is grounded in sub-cultural expression. Each season the key garments are put together to create the latest looks in popular urban culture. The assortment focuses on denim, hoodies, jersey, graphic tees and is worn with the key jackets of the season. Inspiration is taken from high-end street-wear, sportswear and skate brands.
Contemporary casualwear for the modern man.

Contemporary casualwear for the modern man. The style is current, masculine, cool and combines a relaxed and sporty vibe with a distinct focus on casual sensibility. The assortment ranges from casual essentials and denim to the seasons key products resulting in a range of effortlessly cool, modern wardrobe staples. Inspiration is taken from the heritage of work wear, college, sportswear and denim.
Suits and tailoring for the modern man.

Suits and Tailoring for the modern man. The style is based on current tailoring and offers well dressed essentials as well as tailored current fashion. The assortment is centered around suits in a variety of fits and models — complemented by impeccable coats, shirts and knits. Inspiration is taken from classic tailoring, and from leading designers and high-end brands that influence commercial fashion.
